review.title: Context-Aware Proactive Content Caching with Service Differentiation in Wireless Networks
review.abstract: Content caching in small base stations (SBSs) or wireless infostations is considered as a suitable approach to improve the efficiency in wireless content delivery. Due to storage limitations, placing the optimal content into local caches is crucial. Cache content placement is challenging since it requires knowledge about the content popularity distribution, which is often not available in advance. Moreover, content popularity is subject to fluctuations as mobile users with different interests connect to the caching entity over time. In this paper, we propose a novel algorithm for context-aware proactive cache content placement. By regularly observing context information of connected users, updating the cache content accordingly and observing the demands for cache content subsequently, the algorithm learns context-specific content popularity online over time. We derive a sub-linear regret bound, which characterizes the learning speed and proves that our algorithm asymptotically maximizes the average number of cache hits. Furthermore, our algorithm supports service differentiation by allowing operators of caching entities to prioritize groups of customers. Our numerical results confirm that by exploiting contextual information, our algorithm outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in a real world data set, with an increase in the number of cache hits of at least 14%.

sections.heading: A. Wireless Caching Entity
sections.text: The caching unit is characterized by a limited storage capacity and a reliable backhaul connection to the core network. In its cache memory, the caching unit can store up to m files from a finite content library, where we assume, for convenience, that all files are of the same size. In order to inform users in its environment of available files, the caching unit periodically sends out information about currently buffered files [17] - [19]. If a user is interested in a file that the caching unit has stored in its cache, he requests the file from the caching unit and is served by localized communication. In this case, no additional load is transferred to the macro cache network or backhaul network. If the file is not stored in the caching unit, the user does not request the file from the caching unit.

sections.heading: C. Context-Specific Content Popularity
sections.text: The popularity of content is generally not static, but depends on the preferences of a user. From a user's point of view, his personal preferences for content may depend on various factors. We refer to such factors as context dimensions and categorize them into the following classes as summarized in Table II. Personal characteristics are, for example, demographic factors (e.g. age, gender), emotional state and previous experiences. User devices refer to the device type (e.g. smartphone, tablet) that is used to access and consume content, as well as their capabilities and battery status. Environmental conditions are determined, for example, by the location of the user 10 and its characteristics, the time of day or the day of the week, and external events (e.g. football game, concert) that may be both periodic and aperiotic. Of course, this categorization of possible context dimensions is not exhaustive and the effects of each individual dimension on the popularity of content are pre-determined by the data, the user may not be able to access those data (e.g. football game, concert), which may be both periodic and aperiotic. sections.heading: VII. EXTENSIONS

sections.heading: A. Exploiting the Multicast Gain
sections.text: So far, we have assumed that during the delivery phase of each time window t, with each content request, a file will be delivered immediately to the requesting user. To this end, however, our algorithm can be expanded to benefit from the broadcast character of the wireless medium through multicasting, which has proven beneficial for caching in small cell networks [13]. To this end, each time window t is divided into a number of intervals. Within each of these intervals, user requests are monitored and accumulated, and after a short waiting period, the user requests monitored in the meantime are served. Such multicast transmissions reduce the traffic required for data transmission. In order to exploit the knowledge acquired so far about the popularity of content, user requests for files with low estimated demand could be served immediately, thereby preventing unnecessary delays in cases where another user request and thus multicast transmission could not be met, for example, with high priority.

sections.heading: C. Asynchronous User Arrival
sections.text: So far, we have assumed that within a timeframe, the very users who are connected to the local caching unit in monitoring the user context will request files after updating the cache content. However, if the user connects asynchronously to the local caching unit, our proposed algorithm should be adjusted. If, after updating the cache content, a user disconnects directly and does not request a file even though he has been considered for cache content placement, it should be taken into account that his vanishing demand is the result of disconnection, i.e. he should be neglected when updating estimated requirements. Therefore, in m-CAC, counters are not updated to disconnect users. If a user connects to the local caching unit after placing cache content, his context has not been taken into account in the caching decision. However, his requests can be used to learn faster by updating the estimated requirements based on his requests.

sections.heading: B. Reference Algorithms
sections.text: We compare the performance of m-CAC with five reference algorithms. The first algorithm is the optimal oracle. This algorithm works on the assumption of foresight, i.e., complete knowledge of user requirements within the coming timeframe. The optimal oracle selects the highest number of requests within this timeframe. The second reference algorithm is called m-UCB, which consists of a variant of the UCB algorithm. UCB is a classic learning algorithm for multi-armed bandit problems [34], which embraces logarithmic regret, not taking into account context information, i.e. logarithmic regret is related to the average expected demand over the entire context space. Whereas in the classical UCB an action is taken in each timeframe, the logarithmic regret is not taken into account.

sections.heading: C. Performance Measures
sections.text: The development of the time or aggregate number of cache hits allows comparing the absolute performance of the algorithms. A relative measure of performance is cache efficiency, which is defined as the ratio of cache hits to aggregate demand, i.e. cache efficiency in% = cache hit + cache miss · 100. Cache efficiency describes the percentage of user requests that can be served by the files cached by the caching unit. Note that even the optimal oracle generally cannot serve all user requests due to the limited cache size.

sections.heading: D. Results

sections.heading: IX. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced a context-sensitive, proactive caching algorithm based on contextual, multi-armed bandits for placing cache content with a local caching unit on a wireless network. In order to deal with unknown and fluctuating popularity of content within the ever-changing local user population, the algorithm regularly monitors context information of connected users, updates cache content, and monitors demand for cached content. As a result, over time, the algorithm learns context-specific content popularity online, enabling proactive customization of cache content according to the fluctuating popularity of local content. In addition, we derived a sublinear 28bound due diligence that describes how quickly the algorithm converts to optimal cache content placement and proves that our proposed algorithm asymptotically evaluates the average number of cache hits in addition to the algorithm's ability to support cache algorithms.

metadata.abstractText: Content caching in small base stations (SBSs) or wireless infostations is considered as a suitable approach to improve the efficiency in wireless content delivery. Due to storage limitations, placing the optimal content into local caches is crucial. Cache content placement is challenging since it requires knowledge about the content popularity distribution, which is often not available in advance. Moreover, content popularity is subject to fluctuations as mobile users with different interests connect to the caching entity over time. In this paper, we propose a novel algorithm for context-aware proactive cache content placement. By regularly observing context information of connected users, updating the cache content accordingly and observing the demands for cache content subsequently, the algorithm learns contextspecific content popularity online over time. We derive a sub-linear regret bound, which characterizes the learning speed and proves that our algorithm asymptotically maximizes the average number of cache hits. Furthermore, our algorithm supports service differentiation by allowing operators of caching entities to prioritize groups of customers. Our numerical results confirm that by exploiting contextual information, our algorithm outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in a real world data set, with an increase in the number of cache hits of at least 14%.
